bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Burton J. Hendrick, May 1, 1924

div1.p: Kean offers an explanation of how his rebuttal letter to Marie Gorgas' article came to be published in New York Times.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Burton J. Hendrick, May 1, 1924
div1.opener:
JHK-mrh
1 May 1924.
Mr. Burton J. Hendrick,
Editor of The World's Work,
Garden City, N. Y.
My dear Mr. Hendrick:
div1.p:
I was greatly pleased to get your second letter
of April 16th., agreeing to publish in The World's Work the correct-
ion with regard to the chapter of the life of Gorgas. I should have,
perhaps, written to you again and thanked you for it, but I did not
want to consume any of your valuable time with unnecessary corres-
pondence.

Today I saw the May number of The World's Work and
have not been able to find any correction in it. Yesterday I had a
note from the Surgeon General to say that the correction had been
published in the New York Times of last Sunday, April 27th. I feel
that an explanation is due as to how this came about.

When your first letter of April 14th., was received
on the 15th., I immediately forwarded it to General Ireland, to whom
Mrs. Reed had also appealed for a correction, with a remark that it
did not appear that you were inclined to make a correction in the
World's Work and suggesting that he do what he thought best in the
matter. General Ireland is a man of action and, assuming from your
letter that you did not want to publish the correction, he sent it on
April 17th. to the New York Times. Meanwhile, on that date, your second
letter of April 16th., which was entirely satisfactory to me, arrived,
and I forwarded it to General Ireland without the loss of an hour's
time. I was out of town for three or four days at Easter and did not
learn of General Ireland's action until the next week. I then looked
up the file of the New York Times but did not find the article. I
then wrote to him asking him to find out what the Times proposed to
do about it as I wished to inform you immediately if they intended to
publish it. He replied that they had had it over a week but he had
heard nothing from them. From their delay I assumed that they did
not intend to print it and as the May number of The World's Work was
already in print, there was nothing to be gained by writing, until
I found out what the Times would do.

As you did not publish it, I am glad to feel
that you have no cause for complaint at the action which Mrs. Reed's
friends saw fit to take in the matter. If you should see fit to
-2-
publish it or an abstract of it in the June issue, it would be an
evidence of your desire to put the truth before the Public, which
would be appreciated by Mrs. Reed's friends.

I find the chapter in the May issue most interesting.
I am delighted to see the obstinate, self-sufficiency of the “Old
Man of the Sea”, Admiral Walker, plainly set forth. I was busy in
Washington at that time fighting Gorgas' battles against the Commiss-
ioners and was in a dull rage against him until the President summar-
ily dismissed him, as a result of the publication of the report of
Dr. C. A. L. Reed of Cincinnati in the journal of the American Medical
Association about his attitude toward sanitation.
div1.closer:
Very Sincerely yours, J. R. Kean,
Colonel, Med. Corps, USA.
